title: Britain fact of the day
content:
But many of theÂ phrases the English grew up withÂ are fading away as younger generations plug into TikTok or other platforms where they learn to call each other â€œKarenâ€ or â€œbasicâ€ like any other rando, instead of sticking with tried and tested indigenous slurs.

Nearly 60% of the Gen Z cohort havenâ€™t heard the insult â€œlummox,â€ according to a study by research agency Perspectus Global. Less than half know what a â€œninnyâ€ is, with only slightly more of them familiar with â€œpratâ€ or â€œtosspot.â€

What a bunch of plonkers.

There was a time when nearly everybody would sling about terms like â€œblighterâ€ or â€œtoe-rag,â€ and sometimes far ruder terms. That was when the British had more of a shared pop culture, often built around television comedies such as â€œOnly Fools and Horses,â€ about a family of likable London con men. People would talk about them in the schoolyard or at work the next morning. Everyone knew what everyone else was talking about, even if it was a load of twaddle.

Here is more from James Hookway at the WSJ.Â  How can those ninnies not know what a ninny is?
